questions.question: While performing a subtotal thyroidectomy, accidental ligation of which artery can potentiallylead to hypoparathyroidism?
Identify the correct pair based on their embryological development.

options.A: Thymus, Inferior parathyroid gland - Third pharyngeal pouch
options.B: Thymus, Superior parathyroid gland - Fourth pharyngeal pouch
options.C: Superior and Inferior parathyroid gland - Third pharyngeal arch
options.D: Thymus, Superior parathyroid gland - Fourth pharyngeal arch

questions.explanation: The thymus and inferior parathyroid glands originate from the third pharyngeal pouch. Theymigrate from the upper neck to the mediastinum during embryonic development. Inferiorparathyroid glands have more variation in their anatomical position due to a long descent.The superior parathyroid glands originate from the fourth pharyngeal pouch. They are moreconstant in their position.MPharyngeal pouch derivativesIVPrimitive tympanic cavityAuditory tubePalatine tonsilParathyroid gland(inferior)-ThymusParathyroid gland(superior)Ultimobranchial body(parafollicular C-cells)OMARROW336

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common site of ectopic parathyroid gland?
questions.explanation: The most common site of the ectopic parathyroid gland is paraesophageal.The common sites of ectopic parathyroid glands are• Paraesophageal - most common• Mediastinal• Intrathymic• Intrathyroidal• Carotid sheath•High cervical or undescendedEctopic parathyroid is the most common cause of persistent or recurrent hyperparathyroidism. Insuch cases, treatment involves surgical removal of the gland.C3High cervicalpositionC4Carotid sheathC7C5C6T1Paraesophageal15T2T3PosteriormediastinumT4T5-Intrathyroidal13-Intrathymic-Anteriormediastinum(nonthymic)AortopulmonarywindowOMARROW

questions.question: What is the most common cause of hypercalcemia in hospitalized patients?
questions.explanation: Cancer is the most common cause of hypercalcemia in hospitalized patients, whereashyperparathyroidism is the most common cause of hypercalcemia detected incidentally inoutpatients. The causes of hypercalcemia in cancer:•Cancers affecting bone like multiple myeloma, leukemia, bony metastasis - cause the bone tobreak down which releases excess calcium into the blood• Pseudohyperparathyroidism - tumours producing parathyroid hormone-related peptide(PTHrP) cause the bone to release calcium into the blood. The most common carcinomaassociated is squamous cell carcinoma of lung.337• Cancers affecting kidneys - failure to remove excess calcium from the blood.•Dehydration caused by nausea and vomiting - difficult for the kidneys to remove calcium fromthe blood properly• Lack of physical activity - causes bone breakdown, releasing calcium into the blood

questions.question: What is the most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism?
questions.explanation: A single adenoma is the most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism. They are mostoften located in the inferior parathyroid glands.Primary hyperparathyroidism is due to excess or non-suppressed PTH secretion from thefollowing:•Single parathyroid adenoma• Multiple adenomas.Hyperplasia• CarcinomaSporadic primary hyperparathyroidism (HPT) is more common than familial (MEN syndrome/familial HPT/ Familial HPT with jaw tumor syndrome). Women are affected more commonly thanmen.

questions.question: Lab investigations in a patient with fatigue and colicky abdominal pains show elevated PTHand calcium, and low serum phosphate. Which of the following ophthalmic findings ispathognomonic of this condition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism. Band keratopathy ispathognomonic of this condition. It is due to the deposition of calcium phosphate crystals in thecornea.In patients with elevated PTH, calcium and phosphate levels are measured. Elevated calcium anddecreased phosphate levels are suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism. Normal calcium andelevated phosphate levels are suggestive of secondary hyperparathyroidism.The image given below shows band keratopathy.338Option A: Kayser Fleischer rings are brownish-yellow rings in the corneoscleral junction due tothe deposition of copper in the cornea.Option C: Ocular chrysiasis is the deposition of gold in the cornea, after repeated parenteraladministration of gold salts.Option D: Hudson Stahli line is a superficial brown line at the junction of the upper 2/3 and lower1/3 of the cornea in an otherwise normal cornea. It is attributed to the deposition of iron.

questions.question: During a clinical trial, it was found that some individuals who showed radioactive uptake onSestamibi scan, showed no other evidence of hyperparathyroidism. They were instead foundto be suffering from a Hurthle cell nodule of the thyroid gland. Which of the followingradioactive tracer tests could be used to rule out the false positives?
questions.explanation: A thyroid-specific tracer like 99Tc-Pertechnetate and subsequent subtraction images could beused to rule out the false positives caused by the solid thyroid nodules such as Hurthle cell nodule.The Sestamibi scanning is a nuclear-based imaging test used to localize the parathyroid glands.Sestamibi is a monovalent lipophilic cation that accumulates in mitochondria. Due to this, there isa difference in the rate at which it gets washed out depending upon the number of mitochondriain each tissue. Parathyroid adenomas often have a high concentration of oxyphilic cells with highmitochondrial content and they retain tracers and have a slower washout compared to the normalglands.In patients with nodular goiter or functional tumors of the thyroid gland, increased uptake ofsestamibi by the thyroid gland makes parathyroid visualization difficult. There are two primarytechniques to differentiate sestamibi uptake by abnormal parathyroid and thyroid tissue:• Dual-isotope subtraction imaging (with sestamibi and either iodine-123 or 99mTcpertechnetate) - 99mTc pertechnetate is taken up only by the thyroid. The 99mTc pertechnetatescintigram is then digitally subtracted from the sestamibi scan to allow parathyroid localization.Single-isotope dual-phase imaging (with sestamibi alone with early and delayed imaging) - sincethe rate of washout from the hyperfunctioning parathyroid gland is slower when compared to thethyroid gland.•The image given below shows the dual-isotope subtraction imaging.339

questions.question: 329A patient presents with polyuria, polydipsia, lethargy and abdominal pain. He had an X-raytaken a few days ago, which is given below. Which of the following investigations would notbe useful in arriving at a diagnosis?

options.B: Ultrasonography of neckDual-energy radiographic absorptiometryd) Angiography of renal arteriesDAILYROUNDSQuestion 9:In a patient with asymptomatic primary hyperparathyroidism, when will you performparathyroidectomy?a) If bone mineral density of > 2.5 SD above peak bone massb) If age >50 years
options.C: In the presence of hypercalciuria but absence of nephrolithiasis
options.D: If creatinine clearance is reduced by 30%

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario with the X-ray showing nephrocalcinosis is suggestive of primaryhyperparathyroidism. Angiography of renal arteries is not a useful investigation forhyperparathyroidism.Nephrocalcinosis occurs in this condition due to hypercalcemia. It decreases renal concentratingability, which may cause polyuria and polydipsia.Clinical features of hyperparathyroidism:• Bones:• Pathological fractures• Subperiosteal bone resorption - 2nd and 3rd digits, most common in radial aspect• Salt and pepper skull• Osteitis fibrosa cystica or VonReckling Hausen's disease of bone• Stones• Multiple and recurrent renal stones - most common••Nephrocalcinosis• Abdominal groans - colicky due to pancreatitis⚫ Psychiatric overtones - raised PTH causing CNS depression and psychiatric symptoms•• Band keratopathy• Features of hypercalcemia -• Vomiting• Confusion340• ECG changes: increased PR interval, shortened QT intervalThe image given below shows salt and pepper skull seen in hyperparathyroidism.•Investigations done in primary hyperparathyroidism:Ultrasonography of the neck is a safe and widely used technique for the localization of abnormalparathyroid glands.• Nuclear medicine scanning with radiolabeled Sestamibi is also a widely used technique.Sestamibi accumulates in parathyroid adenomas. This radionuclide is concentrated in the thyroidand parathyroid tissue but usually washes out of normal thyroid tissue in under an hour. Itpersists in abnormal parathyroid tissue.Dual-energy radiographic absorptiometry is a useful tool to demonstrate skeletal involvement inprimary hyperparathyroidism.The image given below shows a radiolabeled Sestamibi scan.341

questions.question: A 55-year-old lady with a history of multiple pathological fractures and renal stones wasdiagnosed with parathyroid hyperplasia involving all four glands. Which of the followingtreatment modalities will you use to treat her?330

options.A: Complete removal of all four glands alone
options.B: Complete removal of three glands with a partial resection of the least affected gland
options.C: Partial resection of the affected glands with autotransplantation of the least affected gland

questions.explanation: Hyperplasia involving all four parathyroid glands is treated by complete removal of three glandswith partial resection of the least affected gland (Subtotal parathyroidectomy). Total cervicalparathyroidectomy with heterotropic transplantation can also be done in this patient.Modes of treatment for parathyroid hyperplasia:•Subtotal parathyroidectomy - The affected glands are completely removed and the least affectedgland is partially resected. The remnants left behind should ideally be 30 mg. A lower gland ispreferred because its location reduces the risk of injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve.• Total parathyroidectomy with heterotopic transplantation - All 4 parathyroid glands are removedand parathyroid tissue is immediately transplanted to the non-dominant forearm. Pockets aremade in the belly of the brachioradialis muscle, and one to two pieces of parathyroid tissuemeasuring 1 mm each are placed into each pocket. A total of 12 to 14 pieces are transplanted.Complications of parathyroidectomy include:• Persistent or recurrent hyperparathyroidism.Hypoparathyroidism• Hungry bone syndrome• Injury to recurrent laryngeal nerve

questions.question: Autotransplantation was done after total parathyroidectomy in a patient with hyperplasia ofall 4 parathyroid glands. Which of the following best describes this procedure?
questions.explanation: Parathyroid is transplanted heterotopically i.e. organ is implanted in another anatomic location.In total parathyroidectomy, all 4 parathyroid glands are removed and parathyroid tissueis immediately transplanted to the brachioradialis muscle in the non-dominant forearm.

questions.question: Parathyroid gland post surgery is commonly transferred to:
questions.explanation: The parathyroid is commonly transferred to the brachioradialis muscle post-surgery. This willfacilitate easy removal if there is disease recurrence after surgery.Parathyroidectomy is indicated in:• Symptomatic primary hyperparathyroidism (HPT):342•Asymptomatic primary HPT with:• raise in serum calcium >1mg/dl of the normal range•>400 mg urinary calcium in 24-hour urine test• < -2.5 Z-score of bone mineral density•Age <50yr and failed medical treatment• Severe cases of secondary HPTParathyroidectomy is performed in neck hyperextension (semi-Fowler position). The thyroidgland is mobilized, and the parathyroid gland with adenoma is identified and resected. Theparathyroid tissue is transplanted to the non-dominant forearm.Pockets are made in the belly of the brachioradialis muscle, and one to two pieces of parathyroidtissue measuring 1 mm each are placed into each pocket. A total of 12 to 14 pieces aretransplanted. This is a type of heterotopic transplant.Miami criteria (confirm the absence of another hyperactive parathyroid): A drop of parathyroidhormone intraoperatively, to more than half the maximum value at 10 minutes postresection isconsidered an adequate resection in a parathyroid adenoma. However, if there is no drop in PTHlevel, then a multi-gland disease is suspected and the surgery is converted to a bilateral neckexploration.Complications of parathyroidectomy include:• Persistent or recurrent hyperparathyroidism.•Hypoparathyroidism (presenting as hypocalcemia)• Hungry bone syndrome• Injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve

questions.question: A 40-year-old woman presents with complaints of numbness around the lips and a tinglingsensation in her fingers. She underwent parathyroidectomy for hyperparathyroidism one yearago. An ECG was done and is given below. What will be your immediate management?331aVRavaveW12V5i hhhhhhhhhh
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and ECG showing a prolonged QT interval (QT interval more than 0.43seconds) is suggestive of hungry bone syndrome i.e. hypocalcemia post parathyroidectomy. Acutesymptomatic presentation of hypocalcemia is treated with IV calcium gluconate.Symptoms and signs of hypocalcemia:• Mild circumoral or digital numbness• Paresthesia• Laryngeal spasms••Cardiac arrhythmiasChvostek sign: This is elicited by gently tapping over the facial nerve in front of the tragus of theear. There is hyperexcitability of the facial muscles, manifesting as a contraction of the muscles.•⚫ Trousseau's sign: This is elicited by making the forearm ischemic by applying asphygmomanometer cuff to the arm and keeping the pressure above systolic blood pressure (SBP)for 5 minutes. The hand goes into a painful carpopedal spasm and assumes the accoucheur's hand343position. (shown in the image below)Acute symptomatic hypocalcemia is an emergency and must be treated with:• 10 ml of 10% calcium gluconate is given slowly through intravenous route• Calcium and vitamin D replacement is given orally• Magnesium supplementation may also be required due to the synergistic actions of calcium andmagnesiumThe continuous need for calcium or vitamin D, 1-year postoperatively is called permanenthypoparathyroidism.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false about secondary hyperparathyroidism?

options.A: Lithium intake may cause secondary hyperparathyroidism
options.B: Calciphylaxis is seen in early stages

questions.explanation: Calciphylaxis (calcific uremic arteriolopathy) is a disseminated calcification seen late in the courseof secondary hyperparathyroidism.In calciphylaxis, the underlying calcification in the vascular and arteriolar walls → ischemicnecrosis → ulceration and gangrene → sepsis → death.It presents as an expanding cutaneous lesion which is predominantly seen in the extremities andlower abdomen. Prognosis is poor and an urgent parathyroidectomy is shown to increase mediansurvival.Causes of secondary hyperparathyroidism:•Chronic renal failure (most common)• Vitamin D3 deficiency• GI malabsorption• Lithium intake.344To minimize the risk of missing parathyroid glands, transcervical thymectomy should beconsidered as a routine part of total parathyroidectomy with autotransplantation and subtotalparathyroidectomy. In addition, careful cervical exploration for secondary hyperparathyroidismshould be carried out.The image below shows calciphylaxis.10

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient with chronic renal failure presents to the OPD with complaints of recentonset pain in her feet. Blood investigation showed elevated PTH levels and normal serumcalcium values. All of the following mechanisms contribute to elevated PTH in this patientexcept

options.A: Stimulation of parathyroid cells by hyperphosphatemia
options.B: Increased secretion of FGF-23 by osteocytes
options.C: Reduced expression of Vitamin D receptors and CaSR (calcium-sensing receptor) in bones332
options.D: Interference with parathyroid kinase C signal transduction pathway and Wnt pathway

questions.explanation: The clinical scenario described here showing elevated PTH and normal calcium levels is that ofsecondary hyperparathyroidism due to renal failure. Interference with parathyroid kinase C signaltransduction pathway and Wnt pathway is the proposed mechanism of secondaryhyperparathyroidism in the setting of lithium consumption and not renal hyperparathyroidism.Causes for increased PTH in secondary hyperparathyroidism due to renal failure:• Abnormal renal tubular reabsorption → hyperphosphatemia → stimulation of parathyroid cells→ elevated PTH• Increased FGF-23 secretion from osteocytes → decreased 1,25 dihydroxyvitamin D → decreasedintestinal absorption of calcium → elevated PTH• Normally, ECF calcium controls PTH secretion by interacting with CaSR. Stimulation of CaSR byhigh calcium suppresses PTH secretion. In chronic renal disease, there is reduced expression ofVitamin D and CaSR by bones → increased skeletal resistance to PTH → elevated PTH.

questions.question: A 32-year-old female patient is undergoing focussed parathyroidectomy for parathyroidadenoma. According to the Miami criteria, for the resection to be considered adequate, theintraoperative drop in parathyroid hormone should be

options.A: More than one third the maximum preoperative value in 10min
options.B: More than one third the maximum preoperative value in half an 30 min
options.C: More than half the maximum preoperative value in 10min
options.D: More than half the maximum preoperative value in 30 min

questions.explanation: Drop of parathyroid hormone to more than half the maximum value at 10 min postresection isconsidered an adequate resection in a parathyroid adenoma by the Miami criteria.345Most of the patients with primary hyperparathyroidism have single adenoma, and thereforeundergo a focused or minimally invasive parathyroidectomy, where the localized abnormalparathyroid gland is removed. Once the gland is removed, the surgeon can ensure that there is noother hyperactive gland remaining by performing an intraoperative PTH assay for Miami criteria.It is based on the principle that the half-life of the PTH is 3-5 minutes. In a single-gland disease,once the gland is removed the PTH levels should drop to >50% of the preoperative PTH levelwithin 10 minutes. However, if there is no drop in PTH level, then a multi-gland disease issuspected and the surgery is converted to a bilateral neck exploration.

questions.question: A 30-year-old woman presented with complaints of fatigue, vomiting, abdominal cramps andbone pain. She had undergone total parathyroidectomy and heterotopic autotransplantationfor the same complaints 8 months ago. Sestamibi scan was done and found to be normal.What is the next step in management?

options.B: Post her for bilateral neck exploration
options.D: Label her as persistent hyperparathyroidism and start her on medical management

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of recurrent hyperparathyroidism which could be due torecurrence in the neck or graft (graft hyperplasia). The next step would be to perform Casnova testto differentiate between them, as Sestamibi scan has ruled out ectopic parathyroid.Casanova test involves selective venous sampling for PTH levels from neck veins and brachialveins. If PTH from the brachial venous sample is >20 times that of neck vein sample, grafthyperplasia is confirmed.Persistent parathyroidism is defined as hypercalcemia that fails to resolve afterparathyroidectomy i.e. within 6 weeks of surgery. Recurrent parathyroidism ishyperparathyroidism that occurs after an intervening period of at least 6 months of biochemicallydocumented normocalcemia. Causes of persistent/recurrent hyperparathyroidism include:••Ectopic parathyroidUnrecognized hyperplasia - graft site hyperplasiaMissed adenoma in normal position• Incomplete resection• Familial hyperparathyroidism• MEN-1 syndromeThe image below summarises the management protocol for a case of persistent/recurrenthyperparathyroidism.*FHH stands for Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia346Evaluation of Persistent hyperparathyroidismpost parathyroid surgeryPositiveRecurrent or persistent HPTConfirm diagnosisRule out FHHReview operativenotes and pathologyNoninvasivelocalization studiesParathyroidectomyYosParathyroidectomyNegativeNSelective venouscatheterization for PTHPositiveIs tumorlocalized?OMARROWNoNegativeFollow-upif mildhypercalcemiaMedical therapy

questions.question: All of the following are indications for surgical intervention of tertiary hyperparathyroidismexcept

options.C: Nodular hyperplasia of the parathyroid gland

questions.explanation: Reduced serum phosphate is not an indication for surgical intervention in tertiaryhyperparathyroidism.Renal transplantation in patients with chronic kidney diseases may be associated withautonomous functioning of the parathyroid gland. This is called tertiary hyperparathyroidismwhere there is hypercalcemic hyperparathyroidism.The indications for surgical intervention in tertiary hyperparathyroidism are as follows:• Subacute severe hypercalcaemia (>3 mmol/L)•Impaired graft function• Nodular hyperplasia of the parathyroid gland(s)• Progressive symptoms for >2 years following transplantation• Worsening bone disease pain, fractures, bone loss-• Renal stones/nephrocalcinosis• Soft tissue or vascular calcifications

questions.question: 333A 75-year-old lady with type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and end-stage renal disease onhemodialysis presents with hypercalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, and elevated PTH. What isthe treatment of choice in this condition?
questions.explanation: The patient's long-standing renal failure and elevated calcium, phosphate, and PTH are suggestiveof tertiary hyperparathyroidism. This form of hyperparathyroidism can be life-threatening, and allpatients with it should be referred for surgical intervention.The surgical procedure of choice for tertiary hyperparathyroidism is subtotal parathyroidectomy.In subtotal parathyroidectomy, the affected glands are completely removed and the least affected347gland is partially resected.Option A: Total parathyroidectomy without an autograft is not a treatment option due to thepostoperative and persistent difficulties in managing the associated hypocalcemia.Option C: Minimally invasive approaches commonly refer to the removal of a localized abnormalparathyroid gland through an incision less than 3cm in length. It is based on the principle thatover 80% of individuals with primary hyperparathyroidism have a single adenoma. It iscontraindicated in multi-glandular disease, lithium-induced hyperparathyroidism, andhyperparathyroidism associated with familial syndromes.Option D: Cinacalcet is a calcimimetic used in the treatment of secondary hyperparathyroidism.The use of calcimimetics in tertiary hyperparathyroidism remains controversial and has not beenapproved for this indication.

questions.question: A 41-year-old man with a history of treatment for Hodgkin's lymphoma in childhood presentswith severe abdominal cramps and right flank pain. He has a firm 2x2cm mass in the front ofhis neck. He has a Calcium of 15.2 mg/dl, normal TSH, markedly elevated PTH, and PGP9.5+on immunohistochemistry. What is the leading cause of mortality in his condition?
questions.explanation: The patient presents with symptoms suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism. Withearly-onset, neck mass, and positive IHC for PGP9.5+, it is concerning for parathyroid cancer.Hypercalcemia is the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in patients with parathyroidcancer.Parathyroid cancer is a rare malignancy and makes up 1% of cases of primaryhyperparathyroidism. History of prior neck radiation is considered to be a risk factor. Patientsusually present a decade earlier than primary hyperparathyroidism (5th - 6th decade), with anequal preponderance in males and females. Patients may present with a neck mass and severelyelevated calcium and PTH levels.Treatment is focused on controlling hypercalcemia and surgery is the mainstay.Option B: Cardiovascular disease is a major contributing cause of mortality in patients withhyperthyroidism and chronic kidney disease.

questions.question: In patients with parathyroid carcinoma, which of the following treatment modalities wouldyou not consider?

options.C: En-bloc excision of the tumor and ipsilateral thyroid lobe with MRND

questions.explanation: Etelcalcetide has no role in the treatment of parathyroid carcinoma. It is ineffective.Etelcalcetide is a calcium-sensing receptor agonist used to treat secondary hyperparathyroidism inadult patients with chronic kidney disease undergoing dialysis.Treatment modalities for parathyroid carcinoma:•Surgical - Bilateral neck exploration + En-bloc excision of the tumor and ipsilateral thyroid lobewith/without MRND (Modified radical neck dissection) in presence of lymph node metastasis.Pharmacological:••⚫ Cinacalcet hydrochloride, a calcimimetic, can reduce PTH levels by directly binding to the CaSR(calcium-sensing receptor) cells on the parathyroid gland; used to control hypercalcemia inrefractory parathyroid carcinoma.348• Azidothymidine (telomerase inhibitor)⚫ Octreotide••Anti-parathyroid hormone immunotherapy• Radiation therapy - for unresectable disease or for palliation of bone metastasesRisk factors for parathyroid carcinoma incude:• Radiation exposure•Hyperparathyroidism jaw bone syndrome• HPRT gene or parafibromin inactivation

questions.question: A 34-year-old man presents with severe hypercalcemia. His father had similar complaints andwas found to have hyperparathyroid-jaw tumour syndrome. Which of the following ispathognomonic of his condition?
questions.explanation: Ossifying jaw fibromas are a pathognomonic feature of hyperparathyroid-jaw tumoursyndrome. It arises due to inactivating mutations in the HRPT2 gene on chromosome 1 q21-32,encoding parafibromin.It is a rare cause of primary hyperparathyroidism with an early onset (32 years) which presentswith severe hypercalcemia. It is associated with an increased risk of parathyroid carcinoma andother conditions like polycystic kidney disease. Surgical intervention may be considered to removeall enlarged glands.Osteitis fibrosa cystica is a feature of hyperparathyroidism but is not considered pathognomonicof any condition.349
